moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4: The Kings Gambit, offering the sacrifice of a pawn for rapid development of pieces.
moves.2... d6 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. Bc4 Nh6 5. c3 a6 6: Courting danger by putting the queen in line with the white rook. Tactics based on this possibility are behind the next few moves.
moves.8. fxe5 dxe5 9. d4 Bd6 10. Nxe5: Winning a pawn, with the Black king still in the centre .
moves.10... Qh4 11. Nf3: Now if 11... Qxe4 12. Re1 pinning the queen
moves.11... Qh5 12. Qe1: Maybe 12. e5 was an even better option here. I think I wanted to avoid queen exchanges with it still on d1.
moves.12... O-O-O 13. e5 Rhe8: Good move, now both black rooks dominate the open central files.
moves.14. b4: Going for an attack on the queenside
moves.16. d5 Ne5: Now if 17. exd7 Nxf3  winning the white queen.
moves.17. Nxe5 Bxe5 18. Bf4 Bxf4 19. Rxf4: Black could have taken the pawn now with 19...Bxe6 and if 20. dxe6 Rd1 pins the white queen, nasty!
moves.19... Ng4: Heading to e5, a good square for the knight.
Finally the bishop is safe, having been in the same spot since move 6.
moves.24. c4 h6 25. Nc3 Ng6: A mistake allowing the kingside to be destroyed.
